intro: Chaerophyllum syriacum, commonly known as the Syrian cow parsley, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its umbel-shaped inflorescence. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and features finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its flowers are small and white, often appearing in clusters, and it blooms from late spring to early summer. Chaerophyllum syriacum is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to dry, sunny environments.
